head.title: Organic Neutral Radical Emitters: Impact of Chemical Substitution and Electronic-State Hybridization on the Luminescence Properties | Journal of the American Chemical Society

meta.content: Organic Neutral Radical Emitters: Impact of Chemical Substitution and Electronic-State Hybridization on the Luminescence Properties

Neutral donor–acceptor (D–A•) organic radicals have recently attracted a great deal of attention as promising luminescent materials due to their strong doublet emission. Here, we consider a series of emitters based on substituted triarylamine (TAA) donors and a radical-carrying perchlorotriphenylmethyl (PTM) acceptor. We evaluate, by means of quantum-chemical calculations and theoretical modeling, how chemical substitution affects the electronic structures and radiative and nonradiative decay rates. Our calculations show that the radiative decay rates are dominated in all instances by the electronic coupling between the lowest excited state, which has charge-transfer (CT) character, and the ground state. On the other hand, the nonradiative decay rates in the case of TAA–PTM radicals that have high CT energies are defined by the electronic hybridization of the CT state with local excitations (LE) on the PTM moiety; also, these nonradiative rates deviate significantly from the gap law dependence that is observed in the TAA–PTM radicals that have low CT energies. These findings underscore that hybridization of the emissive state with high-energy states can, in analogy with the intensity borrowing effect commonly invoked for radiative transitions, enhance as well the nonradiative decay rates. Our results highlight that in order to understand the emissive properties of D–A• radicals, it is required that the electronic hybridization of the CT states with both the ground and the LE states be properly considered.

div.p:
Neutral donor–acceptor (D–A
•
) organic radicals have recently attracted a great deal of attention as promising luminescent materials due to their strong doublet emission. Here, we consider a series of emitters based on substituted triarylamine (TAA) donors and a radical-carrying perchlorotriphenylmethyl (PTM) acceptor. We evaluate, by means of quantum-chemical calculations and theoretical modeling, how chemical substitution affects the electronic structures and radiative and nonradiative decay rates. Our calculations show that the radiative decay rates are dominated in all instances by the electronic coupling between the lowest excited state, which has charge-transfer (CT) character, and the ground state. On the other hand, the nonradiative decay rates in the case of TAA–PTM radicals that have high CT energies are defined by the electronic hybridization of the CT state with local excitations (LE) on the PTM moiety; also, these nonradiative rates deviate significantly from the gap law dependence that is observed in the TAA–PTM radicals that have low CT energies. These findings underscore that hybridization of the emissive state with high-energy states can, in analogy with the intensity borrowing effect commonly invoked for radiative transitions, enhance as well the nonradiative decay rates. Our results highlight that in order to understand the emissive properties of D–A
•
radicals, it is required that the electronic hybridization of the CT states with both the ground and the LE states be properly considered.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
There is currently much interest in the exploration of stable organic neutral radicals for various applications including optoelectronics, spintronics, magnets, switches, or quantum information technologies.
(1−10)
Significant advances were very recently achieved in the field of radical emitters for electroluminescence.
(1,11−14)
It was found, for instance, that donor–acceptor (D–A
•
) molecules, designed by attaching a carbazole or triarylamine (TAA) electron-rich donating group (D) to an electron-poor radical-carrying (A
•
) tris(2,4,6-trichlorophenyl)methyl (TTM) or perchlorotriphenylmethyl (PTM) moiety, are stable and highly luminescent.
(11,12,15)

In conventional closed-shell fluorescent emitters, electrical excitation leads to formation of both emissive singlet and nonemissive triplet excitons in a ratio of 1:3. In contrast, in organic neutral radical emitters, both the first excited electronic state (D
1
) and the ground state (D
0
), which are the states involved in electroluminescence, are spin doublets. As a result, these radical emitters provide a simple way to circumvent the 75% energy loss that plagued the first-generation organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) based on traditional organic emitters. Li and co-workers reported that OLEDs based on the TTM-3NCz (9-(naphthalene-2-yl)-9
H
-carbazole) radical emitter display external quantum efficiencies (EQEs) as large as 27%.
(11)
While it was demonstrated that D–A
•
radicals allow the development of very efficient deep-red/red OLEDs, there remains a lack of understanding of how the D–A
•
strategy can be exploited to being the device emission to higher energies while maintaining large EQEs.

The lowest excited D
1
state in D–A
•
radicals based on TTM or PTM (A
•
) moieties is characterized by a charge-transfer (CT) electronic configuration (D
•+
–A
–
).
(12,14−16)
Therefore, the energy (
E
CT
) of the D
1
state can be modulated by modifying the donor strength of the electron-rich moiety, which provides a simple route to develop color-tunable radical OLEDs. Indeed, Heckmann et al.
(15)
have shown that via chemical substitution of TAA donors, the CT energy of a series of TAA–PTM radicals (see the chemical structures in
Figure
1
) can be varied over about 1 eV. In addition, the donor strength is expected to affect the radiative (
k
r
CT
) and nonradiative (
k
nr
CT
) decay rate constants of the CT D
1
state. Interestingly, the time-resolved fluorescence and transient absorption spectroscopy data
(15)
measured by Heckmann et al. show that instead of the expected energy gap law dependence of
k
nr
CT
as a function of CT energy (i.e.,

nr

∝ exp[−
βE
CT
], where β is a constant, the
k
nr
CT
rate constants in their series of TAA–PTM radicals hardly depend on
E
CT
; this is especially the case when the TAA moieties have a weak donor strength. These experimental results underline that in order to develop a new generation of efficient radical emitters for OLEDs, it is critical to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the factors that define the fluorescence properties of organic neutral radicals.

div.div:
Here, we develop a theoretical framework that allows us to rationalize the relationships among chemical structure, electronic structure, and radiative and nonradiative decay rates in donor–acceptor radical emitters. We use this approach to rationalize the experimental results reported for the series of TAA–PTM radicals shown in
Figure
1
. We show that the luminescence properties of the D–A
•
radicals are strongly altered by the electronic hybridization between the (D
•+
–A
–
) charge-transfer state and the local excitation (LE) states on the acceptor moiety.

div.div:
The electronic structures and microscopic parameters required for the theoretical analyses were derived at the density functional theory (DFT) level using the screened range-separated hybrid (SRSH) functional LC-ωhPBE with the 6-31G** basis set. The
Supporting Information
(SI) provides all of the details regarding the computational methodology.

The excited-state energies obtained by means of these calculations compare very well with the experimental data for the TAA–PTM radicals, see
Figure S1
. All
2
–
8
radicals have a non-Aufbau ground-state electronic configuration (
Figures
2
a and
S2
), i.e., the energy of the singly occupied molecular orbital (SOMO), which is mainly located on the PTM moiety, is lower than the energy of the doubly occupied highest molecular orbital (HOMO), which is primarily confined to the TAA moieties. The same non-Aufbau ground-state electronic configuration has been found in other similar radicals.
(12,17−20)
Figure
2
a underscores that the HOMO energies strongly evolve as the electron-donating strength of the TAA moieties weakens in going from
2
(MeO) to
8
(NO
2
); on the other hand, the LUMO and SOMO energies remain nearly unchanged.

The hybridization of a CT state with bright LE states is commonly invoked in the literature to explain an unexpectedly large emission (or absorption) intensity, an effect referred to as intensity borrowing.
(25−28)
Here, we highlight a previously overlooked feature, which is that a related “intensity borrowing” effect exists for nonradiative transitions, due to the hybridization of the CT state with dark LE states.

Finally, it is worth noting that Abdurahman et al.
(13)
recently suggested that it is the coupling (hybridization) of the CT state with higher energy LE states that explains why D–A
•
radicals based on TTM and carbazole moieties are bright even though the TTM radical is dark. Our calculations demonstrate that in TAA–PTM radicals the radiative rates are dominated by the coupling between the CT and the ground states, an interaction that was not considered in ref
(13)
. A detailed comparison of the radiative and nonradiative transitions in D–A
•
radicals based on TTM and PTM will be discussed elsewhere.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The impact of chemical substitutions on the electronic structure and luminescence properties of D–A
•
radicals based on triarylamine and perchlorotriphenylmethyl moieties was comprehensively evaluated at the screened range-separated hybrid DFT level. In agreement with experiment, our calculations show that the modulation of the donor strength induced by chemical substitution of the triarylamine moiety significantly influences the energy of the lowest excited state, which has a dominant charge-transfer character.

As the donor strength decreases and the CT energy increases, the nonradiative transition rates display a crossover: they evolve from being defined by the hybridization (electronic coupling) of the CT state with the ground state to being defined by the hybridization of the CT state with local excitation dark states largely confined to the PTM moiety. These results demonstrate that nonradiative transitions can undergo intensity borrowing effects via the coupling to dark states. In contrast, the radiative decay rates for all TAA–PTM radicals are dominated by the coupling of the CT state with just the ground state.

Our work underscores that the hybridization of the CT states with both the ground state and the LE states has to be properly considered in order to derive a comprehensive understanding of the radiative and nonradiative decay rates in D–A
•
radicals. Our results also imply that in order to design a new generation of efficient D–A
•
radicals with high-energy emission, it is important to consider A
•
moieties with local excitation state energies higher than those found in TTM and PTM radicals.

Air-Stable Organic Radicals: New-Generation Materials for Flexible Electronics
Ji, Lei; Shi, Junqing; Wei, Juan; Yu, Tao; Huang, Wei
Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany)

0935-9648

(
Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
)
A review. In the last few years, air-stable org. radicals and radical polymers have attracted tremendous attention due to their outstanding performance in flexible electronic devices, including transistors, batteries, light-emitting diodes, thermoelec. and photothermal conversion devices, and among many others. The main issue of radicals from lab. studies to real-world applications is that the no. of known air-stable radicals is very limited, and the radicals that have been used as materials are even less. Here, the known and newly developed air-stable org. radicals are summarized, generalizing the way of observing air-stable radicals. The special elec. and photophys. properties of org. radicals and radical polymers are interpreted, which give radicals a wide scope for various of potential applications. Finally, the exciting applications of radicals that have been achieved in flexible electronic devices are summarized. The aim herein is to highlight the recent achievements in radicals in chem., materials science, and flexible electronics, and further bridge the gap between these three disciplines.

The nitroxyl radical 1-Me-2-azaadamantane N-oxyl (Me-AZADO) exhibits magnetic bistability arising from a radical/dimer interconversion. The transition from the rotationally disordered paramagnetic plastic crystal, Me-AZADO, to the ordered diamagnetic cryst. phase, (Me-AZADO)2, was conclusively demonstrated by crystal structure detn. from high-resoln. powder diffraction data and by solid-state NMR spectroscopy. The phase change is characterized by a wide thermal hysteresis with high sensitivity to even small applied pressures. The mol. dynamics of the phase transition from the plastic crystal to the conventional cryst. phase was tracked by solid-state (1H and 13C) NMR and EPR spectroscopies.

A review. Recently, long-lived, org. radical species have attracted much attention from chemists and material scientists because of their unique electronic properties derived from their magnetic spin and singly occupied MOs. Most stable and persistent org. radicals are heteroatom-centered radicals, whereas carbon-centered radicals are generally very reactive and therefore have had limited applications. Because the phys. properties of carbon-centered radicals depend predominantly on the topol. of the π-electron array, the development of new carbon-centered radicals is key to new basic mol. skeletons that promise novel and diverse applications of spin materials. This account summarizes our recent studies on the development of novel carbon-centered radicals, including phenalenyl, fluorenyl, and triarylmethyl radicals.

Embedding a magnetic electroactive mol. in a three-terminal junction allows for the fast and local elec. field control of magnetic properties desirable in spintronic devices and quantum gates. Here, we provide an example of this control through the reversible and stable charging of a single all-org. neutral diradical mol. By means of inelastic electron tunnel spectroscopy we show that the added electron occupies a MO distinct from those contg. the two radical electrons, forming a spin system with three antiferromagnetically coupled spins. Changing the redox state of the mol. therefore switches on and off a parallel exchange path between the two radical spins through the added electron. This elec. controlled gating of the intramol. magnetic interactions constitutes an essential ingredient of a single-mol. √(SWAP) quantum gate.

A review. The novel and exciting field of mol. spintronics has recently attracted a great deal of interest and promising results have already been reported. The utilization of org. radicals that could favor spin polarization and conservation during transport offers new possibilities; however, first a fundamental investigation of these materials, esp. those deposited on surfaces, is required. Here we highlight our recent results regarding the functionalization of surfaces with polychlorotriphenylmethyl (PTM) radicals following five different strategies in which interactions of different nature are involved (i.e. van der Waals, electrostatic, coordination bond and covalent bond). In all cases, it was proved that the magnetic character of the mol. persists on the surface.

The review presents an overview of the org. radicals that have been designed and synthesized recently, and their magnetic properties are discussed. The π-conjugated org. radicals such as phenalenyl systems, functionalized nitronylnitroxides, benzotriazinyl, bisthiazolyl, aminyl-based radicals and polyradicals, and Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF)-based H-bonded radicals have been considered. The examples show that weak supramol. interactions play a major role in modulating the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic properties. The new emerging direction of zethrenes, org. polyradicals, and macrocyclic polyradicals with their attractive and discrete architectures has been deliberated. The magnetic studies delineate the singlet-triplet transitions and their corresponding energies in these org. radicals. We have also made an attempt to collate the major org. neutral radicals, radical ions and radical zwitterions that have emerged over the last century.

Org. materials with unpaired electrons along with the discovery of their unique properties have fascinated scientists for over a century. The development of open-shell mols. has recently been rekindled as the result of improved synthetic strategies and spectroscopic techniques. In this focus review, we provide an overview of open-shell polymers and small-mols. org. semiconductors. We review strategies toward mol. magnets or spin-polarized magnetic org. semiconductors that encompasses incorporation of stable radical groups directly into the backbone of org. semiconductors or prepg. highly conjugated ladder-type mols. based on open-shell Kekule´-type structures to enable efficient spin delocalization along the conjugation length. Spins in solids or in mols. possess discrete energy levels, and the assocd. quantum states can be tuned and coherently manipulated by means of external electromagnetic fields. Spins therefore provide one of the simplest platforms to encode a quantum bit (qubit), the elementary unit of future quantum computers. Performing any useful computation demands much more than realizing a robust qubit-one also needs a large no. of qubits and a reliable manner with which to integrate them into a complex circuitry that can store and process information and implement quantum algorithms. This 'scalability' is arguably one of the challenges for which a chem.-based bottom-up approach is best-suited. Mols., being much more versatile than atoms, and yet microscopic, are the quantum objects with the highest capacity to form non-trivial ordered states at the nanoscale and to be replicated in large nos. using chem. tools.

A review. Org. radicals can potentially play important roles in functional materials owing to an unpaired electron, but they are usually highly reactive and difficult to use. Therefore, stabilization of org. radicals is important. Among org. radicals, carbon-centered radicals are promising because of their trivalent nature, which enables structural diversity and elaborate designs, but they are also less stable because of the reactivities towards carbon-carbon bond formation and atm. oxygen. Recently, stable carbon-centered radicals across diverse mol. platforms have been increasingly explored. This Minireview highlights these newly explored, stable carbon-centered radicals, with a focus on porphyrinoid-stabilized radicals because of their remarkable spin delocalization abilities.

Efficient radical-based light-emitting diodes with doublet emission
Ai, Xin; Evans, Emrys W.; Dong, Shengzhi; Gillett, Alexander J.; Guo, Haoqing; Chen, Yingxin; Hele, Timothy J. H.; Friend, Richard H.; Li, Feng

Org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs)1-5, quantum-dot-based LEDs6-10, perovskite-based LEDs11-13 and micro-LEDs14,15 have been championed to fabricate lightwt. and flexible units for next-generation displays and active lighting. Although there are already some high-end com. products based on OLEDs, costs must decrease while maintaining high operational efficiencies for the technol. to realize wider impact. Here we demonstrate efficient action of radical-based OLEDs16, whose emission originates from a spin doublet, rather than a singlet or triplet exciton. While the emission process is still spin-allowed in these OLEDs, the efficiency limitations imposed by triplet excitons are circumvented for doublets. Using a luminescent radical emitter, we demonstrate an OLED with max. external quantum efficiency of 27 per cent at a wavelength of 710 nm-the highest reported value for deep-red and IR LEDs. For a std. closed-shell org. semiconductor, holes and electrons occupy the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied MOs (HOMOs and LUMOs), resp., and recombine to form singlet or triplet excitons. Radical emitters have a singly occupied MO (SOMO) in the ground state, giving an overall spin-1/2 doublet. If-as expected on energetic grounds-both electrons and holes occupy this SOMO level, recombination returns the system to the ground state, giving no light emission. However, in our very efficient OLEDs, we achieve selective hole injection into the HOMO and electron injection to the SOMO to form the fluorescent doublet excited state with near-unity internal quantum efficiency.

With their unusual electronic structures, org. radical mols. display luminescence properties potentially relevant to lighting applications; yet, their luminescence quantum yield and stability lag behind those of other org. emitters. Here, we designed donor-acceptor neutral radicals based on an electron-poor perchlorotriphenylmethyl or tris(2,4,6-trichlorophenyl)methyl radical moiety combined with different electron-rich groups. Exptl. and quantum-chem. studies demonstrate that the mols. do not follow the Aufbau principle: the singly occupied MO is found to lie below the highest (doubly) occupied MO. These donor-acceptor radicals have a strong emission yield (up to 54%) and high photostability, with estd. half-lives reaching up to several months under pulsed UV laser irradn. Org. light-emitting diodes based on such a radical emitter show deep-red/near-IR emission with a maximal external quantum efficiency of 5.3%. Our results provide a simple mol.-design strategy for stable, highly luminescent radicals with non-Aufbau electronic structures.

Radical-carrying org. mols. have received significant attention to bypass the issue related to harvesting triplet excitons in current light-emitting materials. While the computational efforts conducted so far have treated these radical emitters as isolated entities, in actual devices, they are embedded in a host matrix and subject to emitter-host interactions. Here, by combining mol. dynamics simulations and d. functional theory calcns., the impact of the host matrix on the optoelectronic performance of radical emitters is evaluated, taking as a representative example the (4-ncarbazolyl-2,6-dichlorophenyl)bis(2,4,6-trichlorophenyl)-Me (TTM-3NCz) radical emitter dispersed in a 4,4-bis(carbazol-9-yl)biphenyl (CBP) host. A morphol. anal. shows that steric effects around the radical centers, carried by the TTM electron-poor moieties of the emitters, disfavor π-π interactions with the host mols., which leads to random intermol. orientations around the TTM moieties. The 3NCz electron-rich moieties of the emitters, however, have much lesser spatial hindrance for intermol. π-π stacking, which modulates the structural and electronic properties of the emitters in the host matrix. The influence of dynamic and static disorders on the radiative and nonradiative recombination processes is also investigated and it is found that the rates of nonradiative recombination are small, which opens the way to 100% internal quantum efficiency for the doublet-based emission process.

Triarylamine-perchlorotriphenylmethyl radicals (TARA-PCTM) may be viewed as open-shell mixed valence donor-acceptor compds. that exhibit strong charge-transfer (CT) bands in the visible to NIR spectral region. While open-shell mols. generally do not fluoresce at RT, the authors obsd. a surprisingly strong fluorescence from the highly polar excited CT state of the TARA-PCTM radicals in the visible and NIR spectral region. The fluorescence quantum yield is enhanced by a factor of up to 150 compared to the unsubstituted perchlorotriphenylmethyl radical. The enhancement depends on the donor strength of the TARA moiety which was tuned by small substituents (OMe, Me, Cl, CN, and NO2) attached to the Ph groups, thus forming donor-acceptor species that mainly differ by the free energy difference of the excited CT state and the ground state. The reorganization parameters of the CT process were extd. by Bixon-Jortner fits to either the absorption or the fluorescence bands. The dynamics of the nonradiative back-electron transfer were studied by time-resolved fluorescence and transient absorption spectroscopy in the ps to ns time regime. The authors obsd. a strong deviation of the back-electron transfer rate from the expected inverted Marcus behavior which might be due to anharmonic effects.

In most radicals the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is the highest-energy occupied MO (HOMO); however, in a small no. of reported compds. this is not the case. In the present work we expand significantly the scope of this phenomenon, known as SOMO-HOMO energy-level conversion, by showing that it occurs in virtually any distonic radical anion that contains a sufficiently stabilized radical (aminoxyl, peroxyl, aminyl) non-π-conjugated with a neg. charge (carboxylate, phosphate, sulfate). Moreover, regular orbital order is restored on protonation of the anionic fragment, and hence the orbital configuration can be switched by pH. Most importantly, our theor. and exptl. results reveal a dramatically higher radical stability and proton acidity of such distonic radical anions. Changing radical stability by 3-4 orders of magnitude using pH-induced orbital conversion opens a variety of attractive industrial applications, including pH-switchable nitroxide-mediated polymn., and it might be exploited in nature.

Theory and practice of uncommon molecular electronic configurations

The electronic configuration of the mol. is the foundation of its structure and reactivity. The spin state is one of the key characteristics arising from the ordering of electrons within the mol.'s set of orbitals. Org. mols. that have open-shell ground states and interesting physicochem. properties, particularly those influencing their spin alignment, are of immense interest within the up-and-coming field of mol. electronics. In this advanced review, we scrutinize various qual. rules of orbital occupation and spin alignment, viz., the aufbau principle, Hund's multiplicity rule, and dynamic spin polarization concept, through the prism of quantum mechanics. While such rules hold in selected simple cases, in general the spin state of a system depends on a combination of electronic factors that include Coulomb and Pauli repulsion, nuclear attraction, kinetic energy, orbital relaxation, and static correlation. A no. of fascinating chem. systems with spin states that fluctuate between triplet and open-shell singlet, and are responsive to irradn., pH, and other external stimuli, are highlighted. In addn., we outline a range of org. mols. with intriguing non-aufbau orbital configurations. In such quasi-closed-shell systems, the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is energetically lower than one or more doubly occupied orbitals. As a result, the SOMO is not affected by electron attachment to or removal from the mol., and the products of such redox processes are polyradicals. These peculiar species possess attractive conductive and magnetic properties, and a no. of them that have already been developed into mol. electronics applications are highlighted in this review.

Tanushi, Akira; Kimura, Shun; Kusamoto, Tetsuro; Tominaga, Moe; Kitagawa, Yasutaka; Nakano, Masayoshi; Nishihara, Hiroshi

Some org. radicals violate the Aufbau principle and have unique electronic structures in which the energy level of the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is formally lower than that of the HOMO . We synthesized a novel org. radical with a SOMO-HOMO converted electronic structure, TPA-R•, a novel donor-acceptor hybrid of triphenylamine (an electron donor), and a stable polychlorinated diphenyl(4-pyridyl)methyl radical (an electron acceptor). TPA-R• exhibited fluorescence in the near-IR region (λmax = 910 nm) in cyclohexane from a polar intramol. charge-transfer excited state. Cyclic voltammetry, absorption spectroscopy, and d. functional theory calcn. revealed the inversion of the SOMO and HOMO levels in the electronic structure of TPA-R•. Addn. of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid to TPA-R• caused a two-step change. Protonation initially occurred on the diphenylpyridylmethyl radical moiety to form TPA-[RH]•+. This protonation induced large modulation in the frontier orbitals, while the SOMO-HOMO converted electronic structure was conserved. Further addn. of the acid caused unprecedented intramol. electron transfer from the triphenylamine moiety to the protonated radical moiety, generating [TPA]•+-RH. TPA-[RH]•+ and [TPA]•+-RH could be switched by changing the acidity of the soln. These results constitute the first example of the multistep switching behavior stimulated by a single external stimulus in the SOMO-HOMO converted non-Aufbau electronic structure and demonstrate its great potential for realizing unique mol. photonic and electronic functions.

It is known that the probabilities of radiative transitions in a medium differ from those in vacuum. Excitation of a fluorescent mol. and its radiative decay are examples of radiative transitions. The rates of these processes in soln. depend on the optical characteristics of the solvent. The radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff. of a fluorescent mol. in soln. are expressed in terms of the intrinsic properties of the fluorescent mol. (electronic transition moments) and the optical characteristics of the solvent (refractive index, group velocity of light). The group velocity does not enter in the final expressions for the radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff.; this means that the dispersion of the refractive index has no effect on these quantities. The expressions for both the radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff. contain the refractive index of the solvent and the local field correction factor. The latter depends on the cavity model, and, for some cavity models, on the shape of the cavity. Four types of cavity models are discussed; for each model the limits of applicability were examd. Exptl. evidence in support of specific cavity models is reviewed.

A unified treatment is given of non-radiative decay processes in large mols. which involve either electronic relaxation between 2 electronic states or unimol. rearrangement reactions in excited electronic states. The present treatment is analogous to the formalism previously applied for the line shape problem in nuclear recoil and in the optical spectra of solids. It was possible to derive theoretical expressions for the non-radiative decay probability so that an arbitrary no. of different mol. vibrations can be incorporated in the vibrational overlap factors. The general expressions obtained here can be reduced to anal. form for 2 limiting cases, which are referred to as the strong coupling case (which corresponds to a substantial horizontal displacement of the potential energy surfaces of the 2 electronic states) and the weak coupling limit (where the relative horizontal displacement of the 2 potential energy surfaces is small). Quant. criteria for the applicability of these 2 coupling limits are provided. In the strong coupling limit the transition probability is detd. by a Gaussian function of the energy parameter (ΔE-EM), where ΔE is the energy gap between the origins of the 2 electronic states and 2EM is the Stokes shift. This limit exhibits a generalized Arrhenius-type temp. behavior in which the transition probability depends exponentially on the energy barrier for the intersection of the 2 potential surfaces. At low temps. the transition probability is detd. by the mean vibrational frequency and is thus expected to reveal only a moderately weak D isotope effect: The weak coupling limit reveals an exponential (or rather superexponential) dependence of the transition probability on the energy gap ΔE. In this limit the transition probability is dominated by the highest vibrational frequency (e.g. the C-H or C-D vibrations) and thus will reveal a marked isotope effect. When semi-empirical ests. of the pre-exponential factors are provided, the approx. theoretical expression for the weak coupling limit is consistent with the available exptl. data on electronic relaxation in large org. mols.

The authors demonstrate that the marked solvent dependence of the rates krad for radiative recombination in some donor (D)-bridge (B)-acceptor (A) mols., which increase with decreasing solvent polarity (i.e., with increasing peak energy 〈ν〉 for charge-transfer fluorescence), can be quant. accounted for in terms of a dominating contribution of (DBA)*-D+BA- mixing, involving intensity borrowing from local (DBA)* electronic excitations. In these DBA mols., the traditional two-level D+BA--DBA coupling scheme is inapplicable. The anal. of the 〈ν〉 dependence of krad for a certain DBA in a series of solvents results in the (DBA)*-D+BA- couplings V*, which are in good agreement with the V* parameters extd. from oscillator strengths for charge-transfer absorption. The V* parameters, which obey the relation V* .varies. exp(-αN) (where N is the no. of bonds in the bridge), det. the rates for nonradiative (DBA)* → D+BA- charge sepn. and recombination from electronically excited states. The (DBA)*-D+BA- mixing is maximized for the isolated, solvent-free DBA mol. For the isolated mols. analyzed herein, the fraction of(DBA)* admixt. within the charge-transfer state is ∼0.02, being even smaller for the solvated mols.

The charge-transfer electronic states appearing at the donor-acceptor interfaces in org. solar cells mediate exciton dissocn., charge generation, and charge recombination. To date, the characterization of their nature has been carried out on the basis of models that only involve the charge-transfer state and the ground state. Here, we demonstrate that it is essential to go beyond such a two-state model and to consider explicitly as well the electronic and vibrational couplings with the local absorbing state on the donor and/or acceptor. We have thus developed a three-state vibronic model that allows us: to provide a reliable description of the optical absorption features related to the charge-transfer states; to underline the erroneous interpretations stemming from the application of the semi-classical two-state model; and to rationalize how the hybridization between the local-excitation state and charge-transfer state can lead to lower non-radiative voltage losses and higher power conversion efficiencies.

For the exciplexes and excited charge-transfer (CT) complexes formed between 9,10-dicyanoanthracene and 2,6,9,10-tetracyanoanthracene as electron acceptors and alkylbenzenes as donors, the radiative rate consts. (kf) increase with increasing emission energy. The increase in kf is attributed to a corresponding decrease in the charge-transfer character of the emitting species. This is explained in terms of the relative contributions of pure ion-pair and locally excited states to the emitting state. With decreasing solvent polarity and with increasing redox energy of the acceptor/donor pair (EoxD - EredA), the energy of the pure ion-pair state is raised and mixing with the locally excited states increases. The dependence of kf on emission energy is analyzed quant. using a three-state model in which mixing among the first locally excited singlet state of the cyanoanthracenes, the pure ion-pair state, and the neutral state is taken into account. Simplified methods for data anal. are also discussed. From the analyses, the relationship between the electronic structures of the exciplex/excited CT complexes and the emission frequency is obtained. For these acceptor/donor systems, the emitting species can be considered to be essentially pure contact radical-ion pairs (>90% CT character) when their emission max. are lower in energy than the 0,0 transition of the acceptor excited singlet states by ca. 5000 cm-1. Values of ca. 1300-1350 cm-1 are obtained for the electronic matrix elements coupling the locally excited and ion-pair states. The corresponding matrix elements for coupling the ion-pair and the neutral states are ca. 750-900 cm-1, which are similar to those estd. previously from studies of the rates of nonradiative electron transfer in closely related species.

An improved understanding of the electronic structure of interfacial charge transfer (CT) states is of importance due to their crucial role in charge carrier generation and recombination in org. donor-acceptor (DA) solar cells. DA combinations with a small difference between the energy of the CT state (ECT) and energy of the donor exciton (ED*) are of special interest since energy losses due to electron transfer are minimized, resulting in an optimized open-circuit voltage. In that case, the CT state can be considered as a resonance mixt., contg. character of a fully ionic state (D+ A-) and of the local polymer excited state (D* A). We show that the D* A contribution to the overall CT state wave function can be detd. by measurements of the polarization anisotropy of CT absorption and emission of polymer:fullerene blends with aligned polymer chains. We study two donor polymers, P3HT and TQ1, blended with fullerene acceptors with different ionization potentials, allowing variation of the ED* - ECT difference. We find that, upon decreasing ED* - ECT, the local excitonic D* A character of the CT state increases, resulting in a decreased fraction of charge transferred and an increased transition dipole moment. For typical polymer:fullerene systems, this effect is expected to become detrimental for device performance if ED* - ECT < 0.1 eV. This however, depends on the electronic coupling between D* A and D+ A-, which we exptl. est. to be ∼6 meV for the TQ1:PCBM system.

A review. In the last few years, air-stable org. radicals and radical polymers have attracted tremendous attention due to their outstanding performance in flexible electronic devices, including transistors, batteries, light-emitting diodes, thermoelec. and photothermal conversion devices, and among many others. The main issue of radicals from lab. studies to real-world applications is that the no. of known air-stable radicals is very limited, and the radicals that have been used as materials are even less. Here, the known and newly developed air-stable org. radicals are summarized, generalizing the way of observing air-stable radicals. The special elec. and photophys. properties of org. radicals and radical polymers are interpreted, which give radicals a wide scope for various of potential applications. Finally, the exciting applications of radicals that have been achieved in flexible electronic devices are summarized. The aim herein is to highlight the recent achievements in radicals in chem., materials science, and flexible electronics, and further bridge the gap between these three disciplines.

The nitroxyl radical 1-Me-2-azaadamantane N-oxyl (Me-AZADO) exhibits magnetic bistability arising from a radical/dimer interconversion. The transition from the rotationally disordered paramagnetic plastic crystal, Me-AZADO, to the ordered diamagnetic cryst. phase, (Me-AZADO)2, was conclusively demonstrated by crystal structure detn. from high-resoln. powder diffraction data and by solid-state NMR spectroscopy. The phase change is characterized by a wide thermal hysteresis with high sensitivity to even small applied pressures. The mol. dynamics of the phase transition from the plastic crystal to the conventional cryst. phase was tracked by solid-state (1H and 13C) NMR and EPR spectroscopies.

A review. Recently, long-lived, org. radical species have attracted much attention from chemists and material scientists because of their unique electronic properties derived from their magnetic spin and singly occupied MOs. Most stable and persistent org. radicals are heteroatom-centered radicals, whereas carbon-centered radicals are generally very reactive and therefore have had limited applications. Because the phys. properties of carbon-centered radicals depend predominantly on the topol. of the π-electron array, the development of new carbon-centered radicals is key to new basic mol. skeletons that promise novel and diverse applications of spin materials. This account summarizes our recent studies on the development of novel carbon-centered radicals, including phenalenyl, fluorenyl, and triarylmethyl radicals.

Embedding a magnetic electroactive mol. in a three-terminal junction allows for the fast and local elec. field control of magnetic properties desirable in spintronic devices and quantum gates. Here, we provide an example of this control through the reversible and stable charging of a single all-org. neutral diradical mol. By means of inelastic electron tunnel spectroscopy we show that the added electron occupies a MO distinct from those contg. the two radical electrons, forming a spin system with three antiferromagnetically coupled spins. Changing the redox state of the mol. therefore switches on and off a parallel exchange path between the two radical spins through the added electron. This elec. controlled gating of the intramol. magnetic interactions constitutes an essential ingredient of a single-mol. √(SWAP) quantum gate.

A review. The novel and exciting field of mol. spintronics has recently attracted a great deal of interest and promising results have already been reported. The utilization of org. radicals that could favor spin polarization and conservation during transport offers new possibilities; however, first a fundamental investigation of these materials, esp. those deposited on surfaces, is required. Here we highlight our recent results regarding the functionalization of surfaces with polychlorotriphenylmethyl (PTM) radicals following five different strategies in which interactions of different nature are involved (i.e. van der Waals, electrostatic, coordination bond and covalent bond). In all cases, it was proved that the magnetic character of the mol. persists on the surface.

The review presents an overview of the org. radicals that have been designed and synthesized recently, and their magnetic properties are discussed. The π-conjugated org. radicals such as phenalenyl systems, functionalized nitronylnitroxides, benzotriazinyl, bisthiazolyl, aminyl-based radicals and polyradicals, and Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF)-based H-bonded radicals have been considered. The examples show that weak supramol. interactions play a major role in modulating the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic properties. The new emerging direction of zethrenes, org. polyradicals, and macrocyclic polyradicals with their attractive and discrete architectures has been deliberated. The magnetic studies delineate the singlet-triplet transitions and their corresponding energies in these org. radicals. We have also made an attempt to collate the major org. neutral radicals, radical ions and radical zwitterions that have emerged over the last century.

Org. materials with unpaired electrons along with the discovery of their unique properties have fascinated scientists for over a century. The development of open-shell mols. has recently been rekindled as the result of improved synthetic strategies and spectroscopic techniques. In this focus review, we provide an overview of open-shell polymers and small-mols. org. semiconductors. We review strategies toward mol. magnets or spin-polarized magnetic org. semiconductors that encompasses incorporation of stable radical groups directly into the backbone of org. semiconductors or prepg. highly conjugated ladder-type mols. based on open-shell Kekule´-type structures to enable efficient spin delocalization along the conjugation length. Spins in solids or in mols. possess discrete energy levels, and the assocd. quantum states can be tuned and coherently manipulated by means of external electromagnetic fields. Spins therefore provide one of the simplest platforms to encode a quantum bit (qubit), the elementary unit of future quantum computers. Performing any useful computation demands much more than realizing a robust qubit-one also needs a large no. of qubits and a reliable manner with which to integrate them into a complex circuitry that can store and process information and implement quantum algorithms. This 'scalability' is arguably one of the challenges for which a chem.-based bottom-up approach is best-suited. Mols., being much more versatile than atoms, and yet microscopic, are the quantum objects with the highest capacity to form non-trivial ordered states at the nanoscale and to be replicated in large nos. using chem. tools.

A review. Org. radicals can potentially play important roles in functional materials owing to an unpaired electron, but they are usually highly reactive and difficult to use. Therefore, stabilization of org. radicals is important. Among org. radicals, carbon-centered radicals are promising because of their trivalent nature, which enables structural diversity and elaborate designs, but they are also less stable because of the reactivities towards carbon-carbon bond formation and atm. oxygen. Recently, stable carbon-centered radicals across diverse mol. platforms have been increasingly explored. This Minireview highlights these newly explored, stable carbon-centered radicals, with a focus on porphyrinoid-stabilized radicals because of their remarkable spin delocalization abilities.

Efficient radical-based light-emitting diodes with doublet emission
Ai, Xin; Evans, Emrys W.; Dong, Shengzhi; Gillett, Alexander J.; Guo, Haoqing; Chen, Yingxin; Hele, Timothy J. H.; Friend, Richard H.; Li, Feng

Org. light-emitting diodes (OLEDs)1-5, quantum-dot-based LEDs6-10, perovskite-based LEDs11-13 and micro-LEDs14,15 have been championed to fabricate lightwt. and flexible units for next-generation displays and active lighting. Although there are already some high-end com. products based on OLEDs, costs must decrease while maintaining high operational efficiencies for the technol. to realize wider impact. Here we demonstrate efficient action of radical-based OLEDs16, whose emission originates from a spin doublet, rather than a singlet or triplet exciton. While the emission process is still spin-allowed in these OLEDs, the efficiency limitations imposed by triplet excitons are circumvented for doublets. Using a luminescent radical emitter, we demonstrate an OLED with max. external quantum efficiency of 27 per cent at a wavelength of 710 nm-the highest reported value for deep-red and IR LEDs. For a std. closed-shell org. semiconductor, holes and electrons occupy the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied MOs (HOMOs and LUMOs), resp., and recombine to form singlet or triplet excitons. Radical emitters have a singly occupied MO (SOMO) in the ground state, giving an overall spin-1/2 doublet. If-as expected on energetic grounds-both electrons and holes occupy this SOMO level, recombination returns the system to the ground state, giving no light emission. However, in our very efficient OLEDs, we achieve selective hole injection into the HOMO and electron injection to the SOMO to form the fluorescent doublet excited state with near-unity internal quantum efficiency.

With their unusual electronic structures, org. radical mols. display luminescence properties potentially relevant to lighting applications; yet, their luminescence quantum yield and stability lag behind those of other org. emitters. Here, we designed donor-acceptor neutral radicals based on an electron-poor perchlorotriphenylmethyl or tris(2,4,6-trichlorophenyl)methyl radical moiety combined with different electron-rich groups. Exptl. and quantum-chem. studies demonstrate that the mols. do not follow the Aufbau principle: the singly occupied MO is found to lie below the highest (doubly) occupied MO. These donor-acceptor radicals have a strong emission yield (up to 54%) and high photostability, with estd. half-lives reaching up to several months under pulsed UV laser irradn. Org. light-emitting diodes based on such a radical emitter show deep-red/near-IR emission with a maximal external quantum efficiency of 5.3%. Our results provide a simple mol.-design strategy for stable, highly luminescent radicals with non-Aufbau electronic structures.

Radical-carrying org. mols. have received significant attention to bypass the issue related to harvesting triplet excitons in current light-emitting materials. While the computational efforts conducted so far have treated these radical emitters as isolated entities, in actual devices, they are embedded in a host matrix and subject to emitter-host interactions. Here, by combining mol. dynamics simulations and d. functional theory calcns., the impact of the host matrix on the optoelectronic performance of radical emitters is evaluated, taking as a representative example the (4-ncarbazolyl-2,6-dichlorophenyl)bis(2,4,6-trichlorophenyl)-Me (TTM-3NCz) radical emitter dispersed in a 4,4-bis(carbazol-9-yl)biphenyl (CBP) host. A morphol. anal. shows that steric effects around the radical centers, carried by the TTM electron-poor moieties of the emitters, disfavor π-π interactions with the host mols., which leads to random intermol. orientations around the TTM moieties. The 3NCz electron-rich moieties of the emitters, however, have much lesser spatial hindrance for intermol. π-π stacking, which modulates the structural and electronic properties of the emitters in the host matrix. The influence of dynamic and static disorders on the radiative and nonradiative recombination processes is also investigated and it is found that the rates of nonradiative recombination are small, which opens the way to 100% internal quantum efficiency for the doublet-based emission process.

Triarylamine-perchlorotriphenylmethyl radicals (TARA-PCTM) may be viewed as open-shell mixed valence donor-acceptor compds. that exhibit strong charge-transfer (CT) bands in the visible to NIR spectral region. While open-shell mols. generally do not fluoresce at RT, the authors obsd. a surprisingly strong fluorescence from the highly polar excited CT state of the TARA-PCTM radicals in the visible and NIR spectral region. The fluorescence quantum yield is enhanced by a factor of up to 150 compared to the unsubstituted perchlorotriphenylmethyl radical. The enhancement depends on the donor strength of the TARA moiety which was tuned by small substituents (OMe, Me, Cl, CN, and NO2) attached to the Ph groups, thus forming donor-acceptor species that mainly differ by the free energy difference of the excited CT state and the ground state. The reorganization parameters of the CT process were extd. by Bixon-Jortner fits to either the absorption or the fluorescence bands. The dynamics of the nonradiative back-electron transfer were studied by time-resolved fluorescence and transient absorption spectroscopy in the ps to ns time regime. The authors obsd. a strong deviation of the back-electron transfer rate from the expected inverted Marcus behavior which might be due to anharmonic effects.

The factors affecting the photoluminescence quantum yields (PLQYs) of π-radicals were studied systematically for the first time through comparing the photophys. properties of the synthesized PTM and TTM radicals. In most radicals the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is the highest-energy occupied MO (HOMO); however, in a small no. of reported compds. this is not the case. In the present work we expand significantly the scope of this phenomenon, known as SOMO-HOMO energy-level conversion, by showing that it occurs in virtually any distonic radical anion that contains a sufficiently stabilized radical (aminoxyl, peroxyl, aminyl) non-π-conjugated with a neg. charge (carboxylate, phosphate, sulfate). Moreover, regular orbital order is restored on protonation of the anionic fragment, and hence the orbital configuration can be switched by pH. Most importantly, our theor. and exptl. results reveal a dramatically higher radical stability and proton acidity of such distonic radical anions. Changing radical stability by 3-4 orders of magnitude using pH-induced orbital conversion opens a variety of attractive industrial applications, including pH-switchable nitroxide-mediated polymn., and it might be exploited in nature.

Theory and practice of uncommon molecular electronic configurations
Gryn'ova, Ganna; Coote, Michelle L.; Corminboeuf, Clemence
Wiley Interdisciplinary Reviews: Computational Molecular Science

The electronic configuration of the mol. is the foundation of its structure and reactivity. The spin state is one of the key characteristics arising from the ordering of electrons within the mol.'s set of orbitals. Org. mols. that have open-shell ground states and interesting physicochem. properties, particularly those influencing their spin alignment, are of immense interest within the up-and-coming field of mol. electronics. In this advanced review, we scrutinize various qual. rules of orbital occupation and spin alignment, viz., the aufbau principle, Hund's multiplicity rule, and dynamic spin polarization concept, through the prism of quantum mechanics. While such rules hold in selected simple cases, in general the spin state of a system depends on a combination of electronic factors that include Coulomb and Pauli repulsion, nuclear attraction, kinetic energy, orbital relaxation, and static correlation. A no. of fascinating chem. systems with spin states that fluctuate between triplet and open-shell singlet, and are responsive to irradn., pH, and other external stimuli, are highlighted. In addn., we outline a range of org. mols. with intriguing non-aufbau orbital configurations. In such quasi-closed-shell systems, the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is energetically lower than one or more doubly occupied orbitals. As a result, the SOMO is not affected by electron attachment to or removal from the mol., and the products of such redox processes are polyradicals. These peculiar species possess attractive conductive and magnetic properties, and a no. of them that have already been developed into mol. electronics applications are highlighted in this review.

Tanushi, Akira; Kimura, Shun; Kusamoto, Tetsuro; Tominaga, Moe; Kitagawa, Yasutaka; Nakano, Masayoshi; Nishihara, Hiroshi

Some org. radicals violate the Aufbau principle and have unique electronic structures in which the energy level of the singly occupied MO (SOMO) is formally lower than that of the HOMO . We synthesized a novel org. radical with a SOMO-HOMO converted electronic structure, TPA-R•, a novel donor-acceptor hybrid of triphenylamine (an electron donor), and a stable polychlorinated diphenyl(4-pyridyl)methyl radical (an electron acceptor). TPA-R• exhibited fluorescence in the near-IR region (λmax = 910 nm) in cyclohexane from a polar intramol. charge-transfer excited state. Cyclic voltammetry, absorption spectroscopy, and d. functional theory calcn. revealed the inversion of the SOMO and HOMO levels in the electronic structure of TPA-R•. Addn. of trifluoromethanesulfonic acid to TPA-R• caused a two-step change. Protonation initially occurred on the diphenylpyridylmethyl radical moiety to form TPA-[RH]•+. This protonation induced large modulation in the frontier orbitals, while the SOMO-HOMO converted electronic structure was conserved. Further addn. of the acid caused unprecedented intramol. electron transfer from the triphenylamine moiety to the protonated radical moiety, generating [TPA]•+-RH. TPA-[RH]•+ and [TPA]•+-RH could be switched by changing the acidity of the soln. These results constitute the first example of the multistep switching behavior stimulated by a single external stimulus in the SOMO-HOMO converted non-Aufbau electronic structure and demonstrate its great potential for realizing unique mol. photonic and electronic functions.

Common pitfalls in relating these parameters are pointed out.

It is known that the probabilities of radiative transitions in a medium differ from those in vacuum. Excitation of a fluorescent mol. and its radiative decay are examples of radiative transitions. The rates of these processes in soln. depend on the optical characteristics of the solvent. The radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff. of a fluorescent mol. in soln. are expressed in terms of the intrinsic properties of the fluorescent mol. (electronic transition moments) and the optical characteristics of the solvent (refractive index, group velocity of light). The group velocity does not enter in the final expressions for the radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff.; this means that the dispersion of the refractive index has no effect on these quantities. The expressions for both the radiative decay rate and the extinction coeff. contain the refractive index of the solvent and the local field correction factor. The latter depends on the cavity model, and, for some cavity models, on the shape of the cavity. Four types of cavity models are discussed; for each model the limits of applicability were examd. Exptl. evidence in support of specific cavity models is reviewed.

A unified treatment is given of non-radiative decay processes in large mols. which involve either electronic relaxation between 2 electronic states or unimol. rearrangement reactions in excited electronic states. The present treatment is analogous to the formalism previously applied for the line shape problem in nuclear recoil and in the optical spectra of solids. It was possible to derive theoretical expressions for the non-radiative decay probability so that an arbitrary no. of different mol. vibrations can be incorporated in the vibrational overlap factors. The general expressions obtained here can be reduced to anal. form for 2 limiting cases, which are referred to as the strong coupling case (which corresponds to a substantial horizontal displacement of the potential energy surfaces of the 2 electronic states) and the weak coupling limit (where the relative horizontal displacement of the 2 potential energy surfaces is small). Quant. criteria for the applicability of these 2 coupling limits are provided. In the strong coupling limit the transition probability is detd. by a Gaussian function of the energy parameter (ΔE-EM), where ΔE is the energy gap between the origins of the 2 electronic states and 2EM is the Stokes shift. This limit exhibits a generalized Arrhenius-type temp. behavior in which the transition probability depends exponentially on the energy barrier for the intersection of the 2 potential surfaces. At low temps. the transition probability is detd. by the mean vibrational frequency and is thus expected to reveal only a moderately weak D isotope effect: The weak coupling limit reveals an exponential (or rather superexponential) dependence of the transition probability on the energy gap ΔE. In this limit the transition probability is dominated by the highest vibrational frequency (e.g. the C-H or C-D vibrations) and thus will reveal a marked isotope effect. When semi-empirical ests. of the pre-exponential factors are provided, the approx. theoretical expression for the weak coupling limit is consistent with the available exptl. data on electronic relaxation in large org. mols.

The authors demonstrate that the marked solvent dependence of the rates krad for radiative recombination in some donor (D)-bridge (B)-acceptor (A) mols., which increase with decreasing solvent polarity (i.e., with increasing peak energy 〈ν〉 for charge-transfer fluorescence), can be quant. accounted for in terms of a dominating contribution of (DBA)*-D+BA- mixing, involving intensity borrowing from local (DBA)* electronic excitations. In these DBA mols., the traditional two-level D+BA--DBA coupling scheme is inapplicable. The anal. of the 〈ν〉 dependence of krad for a certain DBA in a series of solvents results in the (DBA)*-D+BA- couplings V*, which are in good agreement with the V* parameters extd. from oscillator strengths for charge-transfer absorption. The V* parameters, which obey the relation V* .varies. exp(-αN) (where N is the no. of bonds in the bridge), det. the rates for nonradiative (DBA)* → D+BA- charge sepn. and recombination from electronically excited states. The (DBA)*-D+BA- mixing is maximized for the isolated, solvent-free DBA mol. For the isolated mols. analyzed herein, the fraction of(DBA)* admixt. within the charge-transfer state is ∼0.02, being even smaller for the solvated mols.

The charge-transfer electronic states appearing at the donor-acceptor interfaces in org. solar cells mediate exciton dissocn., charge generation, and charge recombination. To date, the characterization of their nature has been carried out on the basis of models that only involve the charge-transfer state and the ground state. Here, we demonstrate that it is essential to go beyond such a two-state model and to consider explicitly as well the electronic and vibrational couplings with the local absorbing state on the donor and/or acceptor. We have thus developed a three-state vibronic model that allows us: to provide a reliable description of the optical absorption features related to the charge-transfer states; to underline the erroneous interpretations stemming from the application of the semi-classical two-state model; and to rationalize how the hybridization between the local-excitation state and charge-transfer state can lead to lower non-radiative voltage losses and higher power conversion efficiencies.

For the exciplexes and excited charge-transfer (CT) complexes formed between 9,10-dicyanoanthracene and 2,6,9,10-tetracyanoanthracene as electron acceptors and alkylbenzenes as donors, the radiative rate consts. (kf) increase with increasing emission energy. The increase in kf is attributed to a corresponding decrease in the charge-transfer character of the emitting species. This is explained in terms of the relative contributions of pure ion-pair and locally excited states to the emitting state. With decreasing solvent polarity and with increasing redox energy of the acceptor/donor pair (EoxD - EredA), the energy of the pure ion-pair state is raised and mixing with the locally excited states increases. The dependence of kf on emission energy is analyzed quant. using a three-state model in which mixing among the first locally excited singlet state of the cyanoanthracenes, the pure ion-pair state, and the neutral state is taken into account. Simplified methods for data anal. are also discussed. From the analyses, the relationship between the electronic structures of the exciplex/excited CT complexes and the emission frequency is obtained. For these acceptor/donor systems, the emitting species can be considered to be essentially pure contact radical-ion pairs (>90% CT character) when their emission max. are lower in energy than the 0,0 transition of the acceptor excited singlet states by ca. 5000 cm-1. Values of ca. 1300-1350 cm-1 are obtained for the electronic matrix elements coupling the locally excited and ion-pair states. The corresponding matrix elements for coupling the ion-pair and the neutral states are ca. 750-900 cm-1, which are similar to those estd. previously from studies of the rates of nonradiative electron transfer in closely related species.

An improved understanding of the electronic structure of interfacial charge transfer (CT) states is of importance due to their crucial role in charge carrier generation and recombination in org. donor-acceptor (DA) solar cells. DA combinations with a small difference between the energy of the CT state (ECT) and energy of the donor exciton (ED*) are of special interest since energy losses due to electron transfer are minimized, resulting in an optimized open-circuit voltage. In that case, the CT state can be considered as a resonance mixt., contg. character of a fully ionic state (D+ A-) and of the local polymer excited state (D* A). We show that the D* A contribution to the overall CT state wave function can be detd. by measurements of the polarization anisotropy of CT absorption and emission of polymer:fullerene blends with aligned polymer chains. We study two donor polymers, P3HT and TQ1, blended with fullerene acceptors with different ionization potentials, allowing variation of the ED* - ECT difference. We find that, upon decreasing ED* - ECT, the local excitonic D* A character of the CT state increases, resulting in a decreased fraction of charge transferred and an increased transition dipole moment. For typical polymer:fullerene systems, this effect is expected to become detrimental for device performance if ED* - ECT < 0.1 eV. This however, depends on the electronic coupling between D* A and D+ A-, which we exptl. est. to be ∼6 meV for the TQ1:PCBM system.
